main.docTitle: Merchant Shipping (Security of Ships and Port Facilities) Rules

section.name: s1
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In these Rules, unless the context otherwise requires—

def.name: Company
def.leadIn: company (公司), in relation to a ship, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the owner of the ship; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any person, including the manager or bareboat charterer of the ship, who has assumed responsibility for the operation of the ship and, on assuming that responsibility, agreed to take over all duties and responsibilities imposed in respect of the ship by the International Safety Management Code;

section.def: company security officer (公司保安官員) means a person designated under rule 9(1)(b);
Declaration of Security (保安聲明) means an agreement reached between a ship and a port facility or a ship with which it interfaces specifying the security measures that each will implement;
interim certificate (臨時證書) means an Interim International Ship Security Certificate issued under rule 16;

International Safety Management Code (《國際安全管理規則》) means the International Management Code for the Safe Operation of Ships and for Pollution Prevention adopted by the International Maritime Organization as amended by the Organization from time to time;
port facility security officer (港口設施保安官員) means a person designated under rule 24(1);
port facility security plan (港口設施保安計劃) means a plan referred to in section 16 of part A of the Code;
security certificate (保安證書) means an International Ship Security Certificate issued or endorsed under rule 14;
security instruction (保安指示) means an instruction given under rule 3;

security level (保安級別) means the qualification of the degree of risk that any suspicious act or circumstance threatening the security of a ship or port facility will occur as set pursuant to section 4.1 of part A of the Code;
ship security officer (船舶保安官員) means a person designated under rule 9(1)(a);
ship security plan (船舶保安計劃) means a plan referred to in section 9 of part A of the Code.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Setting of security levels
section.content: The Director shall set security levels pursuant to section 4.1 of part A of the Code by publishing a notice which is accessible through the Internet.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Security instructions

subsection.leadIn: Where security level 3 is set by the Director, the Director may give such security instructions as he thinks fit to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Hong Kong ship;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a non-Hong Kong ship in the waters of Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a designated port facility.

subsection.leadIn: Security instructions referred to in subrule (1) shall be given by such means as the Director thinks fit including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publishing a notice which is accessible through the Internet;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making a public announcement by radio or television;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: placing a notice in any daily newspaper in circulation in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: issuing a notice to the company or the master of the ship or the management of the designated port facility.

subsection.leadIn: The company and the master of a ship or the management of a designated port facility to which a security instruction is given by the Director under subrule (1) shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: ensure that the security instruction is complied with without undue delay; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where it is impracticable to comply with paragraph (a), notify the Director of that fact without undue delay.

subsection.content: If a security instruction given to a ship in the waters of Hong Kong has been received by the company or the master of the ship but the company or the master, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with subrule (4), the company or the master (as the case may be) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

If a security instruction given to a designated port facility has been received by the management of the port facility but the management, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with subrule (4), the management commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000 and to imprisonment for 3 years.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Delegation of functions to recognized security organizations
section.content: Subject to the exceptions specified in section 4.3 of part A of the Code, the Director may, in writing, delegate to a recognized security organization his functions relating to security of ships or port facilities under Chapter XI-2 of the Convention and part A of the Code.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Declaration of closed area

subsection.content: If the Director reasonably believes that, in order to abate or contain any security threat, it is necessary to close any area of the waters of Hong Kong to all vessels or any class or type of vessels, he may declare that area to be an area closed to those vessels or that class or type of vessels, as the case may be.

If the master of a vessel, without reasonable excuse, causes the vessel to enter a closed area in contravention of a declaration under subrule (1), he commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: The Director shall make a declaration under subrule (1) by such means as he thinks fit including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publishing a notice which is accessible through the Internet;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: making a public announcement by radio or television; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: placing a notice in any daily newspaper in circulation in Hong Kong.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Hong Kong ships to comply with the Convention
section.content: A Hong Kong ship shall comply with regulations 4, 6 and 8 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention.

section.name: s7
section.heading: Non-Hong Kong ships to comply with the Convention

subsection.content: A non-Hong Kong ship in Hong Kong shall comply with regulations 4, 6 and 8 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention.
A non-Hong Kong ship intending to enter Hong Kong shall comply with regulations 4 and 9.2 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention.

section.name: s8
section.heading: Companies to comply with the Convention

subsection.content: The company of a ship shall comply with regulations 4, 5 and 8 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention.

The company of a ship shall provide the master, company security officer and ship security officer of the ship with such supports as are necessary for each of them to perform their respective functions under Chapter XI-2 of the Convention and part A of the Code.

section.name: s9
section.heading: Ship security officers and company security officers

subsection.leadIn: The company of a ship shall designate for the ship—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ship security officer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a company security officer.

subsection.content: A ship security officer and a company security officer shall comply with the provisions of part A of the Code that respectively apply to each of them and take into account the guidance contained in part B of the Code.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Control of ships in Hong Kong

subsection.content: The Director may impose any control measures referred to in regulation 9.1 or 9.3 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention on a ship in the waters of Hong Kong.
The master of a ship shall, without undue delay, act upon any direction given pursuant to the regulation referred to in subrule (1) by the Director.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Control of ships intending to enter Hong Kong

subsection.content: The Director may impose any control measures referred to in regulation 9.2 or 9.3 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention on a ship intending to enter the waters of Hong Kong.
The master of a ship shall, without undue delay, act upon any direction given pursuant to the regulation referred to in subrule (1) by the Director.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Maintenance of security system on Hong Kong ships
section.content: The company and the master of a Hong Kong ship shall ensure that the security system and the associated security equipment of the ship that have been verified are properly maintained as required under section 19.1.4 of part A of the Code.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Certificates for Hong Kong ships

subsection.content: The company and the master of a Hong Kong ship shall ensure that the ship holds a valid security certificate or an interim certificate.
The master of a Hong Kong ship shall ensure that the ship has on board either of the certificates referred to in subrule (1) while the ship is engaged on international voyage.
The master of a Hong Kong ship who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with subrule (2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 3.

section.name: s14
section.heading: International Ship Security Certificates

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subrule (2), an International Ship Security Certificate may, on application by the company of a Hong Kong ship, be issued or endorsed in respect of the ship by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a recognized security organization that is authorized in writing by the Director to issue or endorse the Certificate; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: upon the request of the Director, another Contracting Government.

subsection.leadIn: A security certificate shall not be issued or endorsed in respect of a Hong Kong ship unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ship security plan of the ship has been approved by the Director or a recognized security organization; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the requirements of verification in accordance with section 19.1 of part A of the Code have been complied with in relation to the ship.

subsection.content: If the Director refuses to issue or endorse (as the case may be) a security certificate, he shall inform the applicant concerned by a notice in writing stating the reasons for his refusal.
A security certificate is valid for such period as specified in the certificate by the person who issued or endorsed the certificate.
A security certificate ceases to be valid if any of the events mentioned in section 19.3.8 of part A of the Code occurs.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Obligations of companies in relation to ships
section.leadIn: Where a security certificate has been issued or endorsed in respect of a ship, the company of the ship shall, on transferring its responsibility for the operation of the ship to another company—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as soon as practicable transmit to that another company all information relating to the certificate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: facilitate the verifications carried out for the ship.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Interim International Ship Security Certificates

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subrule (2), in a case falling within section 19.4.1 of part A of the Code, an Interim International Ship Security Certificate may on application by the company of a Hong Kong ship be issued pursuant to section 19.4.2 of part A of the Code in respect of the ship by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Director; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a recognized security organization that is authorized in writing by the Director to issue the Certificate.

subsection.content: An interim certificate shall not be issued in respect of a Hong Kong ship unless the requirements specified in section 19.4.2 of part A of the Code are verified to have been complied with in relation to the ship.
If the Director refuses to issue an interim certificate, he shall inform the applicant concerned by a notice in writing stating the reasons for his refusal.

subsection.leadIn: An interim certificate is valid until—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expiration of 6 months from its date of issue; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a security certificate is issued in respect of the ship,

section.name: s17
section.heading: Cancellation of certificates

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by notice in writing to the company of a ship, cancel a security certificate issued or endorsed in respect of the ship if he has reason to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: regulation 4, 6 or 8 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention has not been complied with in relation to the ship; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the certificate was issued or endorsed on the basis of false or erroneous information.

subsection.leadIn: The Director may, by notice in writing to the company of a ship, cancel an interim certificate issued in respect of the ship if he has reason to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any of the requirements specified in section 19.4.2 of part A of the Code has not been complied with in relation to the ship; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the certificate was issued on the basis of false or erroneous information.

subsection.content: The Director shall give reasons for cancelling a certificate.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Hong Kong ships outside Hong Kong to comply with requirements of security levels

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subrule (2), where a security level is set by the Director, the company and the master of a Hong Kong ship outside Hong Kong shall ensure that the ship, without undue delay—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complies with the requirements specified in section 7 of part A of the Code in respect of the security level; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: implements the preventive and protective measures specified in its ship security plan in respect of the security level.

subsection.content: If a Hong Kong ship is in the waters of another party to the Convention and the security level set by the government of that party is higher than that set by the Director, the ship shall act on the security level set by that government as if the security level was set by the Director.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Ships in Hong Kong waters to comply with requirements of security levels

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subrule (2), where a security level is set by the Director, the company and the master of a ship in the waters of Hong Kong shall ensure that the ship, without undue delay—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complies with the requirements specified in section 7 of part A of the Code in respect of the security level; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: implements the preventive and protective measures specified in its ship security plan in respect of the security level.

subsection.content: Subrule (1) does not apply if a ship referred to in that subrule has complied with the requirements specified in section 7 of part A of the Code in respect of a security level higher than that set by the Director and has implemented the preventive and protective measures specified in its ship security plan in respect of that higher level.

If the company or the master of a ship, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with subrule (1), the company or the master (as the case may be) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Duty to notify the Director of non-compliance

subsection.leadIn: The master of a ship shall, without undue delay, notify the Director of the details of any non-compliance by the ship with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any of the requirements specified in relation to the ship in rule 18; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any of the requirements specified in relation to the ship in rule 19.

subsection.content: The master of a ship who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with subrule (1)(b) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Ships to complete and keep Declarations of Security

subsection.content: If a ship is requested by the Director under section 5 of part A of the Code to complete a Declaration of Security, the master or the ship security officer of the ship shall, without undue delay, complete the Declaration of Security in the manner specified in that section.

After completing a Declaration of Security in respect of a Hong Kong ship, the master or the ship security officer, as the case may be, of the ship shall keep the Declaration of Security on board during the next 10 calls of the ship at any port facility.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Duty to keep information and records

subsection.leadIn: A ship intending to enter the waters of Hong Kong shall keep on board the information specified in—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: regulation 5 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: regulation 9.2.1 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention on—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: where the ship has previously called at not less than 10 port facilities, the last 10 occasions where the ship called at port facilities immediately before it intends to enter the waters of Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: where the ship has previously called at less than 10 port facilities, all occasions where the ship called at port facilities immediately before it intends to enter the waters of Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: A Hong Kong ship shall keep on board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ship security plan of the ship developed and approved in accordance with section 9 of part A of the Code;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all approvals (if any) for amendment to the ship security plan given pursuant to section 9 of part A of the Code;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the information specified in regulation 5 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in the manner specified in section 10 of part A of the Code, the records specified in section 10.1 of that part for a period of not less than 3 years.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Designated port facilities to comply with the Convention
section.content: A designated port facility shall comply with regulation 10.1 of Chapter XI-2 of the Convention.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Port facility security officers

subsection.content: The management of a designated port facility shall designate a port facility security officer for the port facility.
A port facility security officer shall comply with the provisions of part A of the Code that apply to him and take into account the guidance contained in part B of the Code.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Port facility security plans
section.content: The port facility security officer of a designated port facility shall ensure that a port facility security plan is developed and maintained for the port facility and submitted to the Director for approval in accordance with section 16 of part A of the Code.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Duty to notify the Director of material change in circumstances
section.leadIn: If, since a port facility security plan of a designated port facility has been approved, there has been any material change in the circumstances that may affect the security of the port facility or the implementation of the port facility security plan, the port facility security officer of the port facility shall, without undue delay—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: report the details of the change to the Director;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cause the port facility security plan to be revised to take into account the change; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: submit the revised port facility security plan to the Director for approval.

section.name: s27
section.heading: Withdrawal of approval of port facility security plans

subsection.leadIn: If the Director has reason to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a material change referred to in rule 26 has occurred in respect of a designated port facility; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the requirements specified in that rule are not complied with in relation to the port facility,

subsection.continued: the Director may, by a notice in writing to the management of the port facility, withdraw his approval of the port facility security plan of the port facility.

subsection.content: The Director shall give reasons for withdrawing his approval.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Designated port facilities to comply with requirements of security levels

subsection.leadIn: Where a security level is set by the Director, the management of a designated port facility shall ensure that the port facility, without undue delay—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complies with the requirements specified in section 14 of part A of the Code in respect of the security level; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: implements the preventive and protective measures specified in its port facility security plan in respect of the security level.

subsection.content: The management of a designated port facility who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with subrule (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Designated port facilities to complete and keep Declarations of Security

subsection.content: If a designated port facility is requested under section 5 of part A of the Code by the Director to complete a Declaration of Security, the port facility security officer of the port facility shall, without undue delay, complete the Declaration of Security in the manner specified in that section.

After completing a Declaration of Security in respect of a designated port facility, the port facility security officer of the port facility shall keep the Declaration of Security for a period of not less than 1 year.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Rectification of non-compliance

subsection.content: If the Director has reason to believe that any requirement of the port facility security plan of a designated port facility is not complied with, he may direct the management of the port facility to rectify the condition of non-compliance within such period as he specifies.

The management of a designated port facility who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with any direction made under subrule (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 5.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Appeals

subsection.leadIn: If the company of a ship is aggrieved by a decision of the Director made in respect of the ship under any of the following provisions, it may appeal to a court of survey in accordance with the Merchant Shipping (Court of Survey) Regulations (Cap. 369 sub. leg. A)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: rule 14 (refusing to issue or endorse a security certificate);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: rule 16 (refusing to issue an interim certificate);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: rule 17(1) (cancelling a security certificate);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: rule 17(2) (cancelling an interim certificate).

subsection.content: If the management of a designated port facility is aggrieved by a decision of the Director made in respect of the port facility under rule 27, the management may appeal to the Administrative Appeals Board against the decision.

subsection.leadIn: An appeal referred to in subrule (1) or (2) may only be made within 14 days after—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant has received a notice referred to in rule 14(3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant has received a notice referred to in rule 16(3);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the company has received a notice of cancellation referred to in rule 17(1) or (2); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the management has received a notice of withdrawal referred to in rule 27(1),

subsection.content: A court of survey may affirm or reverse a decision appealed against.
The lodging of an appeal under this rule does not by itself operate as a stay of execution of a decision of the Director.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Fees

subsection.leadIn: The Director may charge fees in respect of the time spent by an authorized officer on providing services relating to any of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: issuing or endorsing a security certificate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: issuing an interim certificate;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: approving a port facility security plan;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: inspecting for the purpose of removal of detention of ships.

subsection.leadIn: The fee under subrule (1) is charged on an hourly basis and the rate is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case where an authorized officer is required to inspect a ship or a port facility in the course of providing services, $3,270 for the first hour or part hour and $1,115 for each subsequent hour or part hour; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, $1,115 for each hour or part hour.
